Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Leaders in Inclusive Astronomy and STEM
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since 2001, the Institute for Scientist & Engineer Educators (ISEE), headquartered at the University of California Santa Cruz, has conducted a series of Professional Development Program (PDP) workshops. These prepare Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) professionals, primarily graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, to become better educators and mentors and to learn inclusive practices that will help increase the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM. This award will continue these activities and will support preliminary studies into how best to expand their impact and how to provide support for their alumni as they implement the strategies learned in the workshops. Four to five hundred new undergraduates per year indirectly benefit from the 39 new PDP alumni each year. The current community of ISEE alumni includes over 650 professionals, most of whom continue to stay in active contact with each other and many of whom seek further training opportunities. Observatory and industry professionals also participate in these programs, which help provide a more highly-trained and diverse workforce, particularly in Hawaii.

The goals of this project are to expand ISEE's impact by: 1) advancing scientists, engineers, and technologists prepared for inclusive teaching and mentoring; 2) advancing ISEE alumni as leaders in equity and inclusion; and 3) developing capacity and structure to enable
a national leadership network. These will be achieved by continuing the PDP workshops and the mentoring programs already in place. They will also develop mechanisms to assist the alumni of these programs as they become leaders in STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Advancing Leaders in Inclusive Astronomy infused inclusive practices into astronomy teaching and mentoring through innovative, research-based professional development. The project expanded training to graduate students and postdoctoral researchers across the U.S., piloted regional chapters to expand impact, and trained telescope personnel to be more effective and inclusive mentors. The project was led by Institute for Scientist & Engineer Educators (ISEE), headquartered at the University of California at Santa Cruz, and included participants at national universities, observatories, and research institutes.

 

ISEE has a long history working with the astronomy community and leveraged it to mobilize early career professionals who are alumni of ISEE programs. The project enabled ISEE to lay the groundwork for further national expansion and had three major goals: 1) advance scientists, engineers, and technologists prepared for inclusive teaching and mentoring; 2) advance ISEE alumni as leaders in equity and inclusion; and 3) develop capacity and structure to enable a national leadership network

 

A central component of this project was the Professional Development Program (PDP), a flexible, multi-year program for scientists and engineers at the early stages of their careers, with a primary focus on graduate students and postdocs. Participants receive training through two multi-day workshops, work on a team to collaboratively design an inquiry activity, and then put their new teaching skills into practice in ISEE-affiliated educational programs or courses. The PDP has a rigorous approach that is designed to fit with participants' demanding research schedules, and enable participation over several years. The PDP is closely aligned with research and theory on effective professional development, and serves as an incubator and testbed for new approaches. This project enabled ISEE to expand participation in the PDP and develop new professional development curriculum.


The Advancing Inclusive Leaders in Astronomy project also enabled ISEE to develop new curriculum for training personnel at observatories to be inclusive and effective mentors, while training approximately 25 mentors each year. ISEE's Mentor Workshop integrates nearly two decades of internship program experience into a unique workshop for engineers, technologists, and scientists who will soon provide a summer project to college students. The workshop is 1.5 days, and typically includes 25-30 mentors from Hawai'i telescopes and tech industry. Before the workshop participants read articles that give them insight into research that relates to diversity and inclusion, ownership, and how in-the-moment interactions with the student have an impact on their overall experience. At the workshop, they discuss what they've read with instructors and other participants, and apply it to the project they have in mind for their student intern. Many participants return and participate in the workshop, creating an enduring community of mentors on Hawai'i Island and Maui where many of the world's premier telescopes are located.


Participating organizations in the Advancing Inclusive Leaders in Astronomy project included:
